Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: This morning, I woke to the sound of my stepmother’s voice echoing through the hallway, reminding me that today was the day we honored our family’s tradition of preparing a special meal together—something she insisted was vital to our unity, especially since I joined the family. I could see the hope in her eyes, the silent plea that I would finally embrace this custom as my own. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart tightened. Today was also the convent’s monthly food drive, a day when all the sisters, myself included, were expected to serve at the shelter, offering meals and comfort to those in need. Mother Superior had spoken just yesterday about the importance of our presence, how our absence would be felt by the community. I stood in the kitchen, torn between the warmth of my family’s expectations and the calling of my faith, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in on me, each demanding my loyalty, each certain that I belonged wholly to them.
